<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->
<A name='111'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">ITEM&#160;7.&#160;&#160;</FONT></B>
</TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">MANAGEMENT&#146;S
    DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF
    OPERATIONS</FONT></B>
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Overview</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    PrivateBancorp was organized as a Delaware corporation in 1989
    to serve as the holding company for The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Chicago, a <I>de novo </I>bank. We completed our initial public
    offering in June of 1999. We currently have five bank
    subsidiaries that operate through 18 offices in Chicago,
    suburban Detroit, St.&#160;Louis, Milwaukee, Kansas City and
    Atlanta. Using the European tradition of &#147;private
    banking&#148; as our model, we provide our clients with
    traditional individual and corporate banking services as well as
    access to mortgage loans offered through The PrivateBank
    Mortgage Company, and wealth management services offered through
    our wealth management division.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We have grown our business organically as well as through the
    acquisition of existing banks and the establishment of <I>de
    novo </I>banks and offices in new markets. We completed our most
    recent acquisition in December 2006 when we purchased Piedmont
    Bancshares, Inc., and its subsidiary, Piedmont Bank of Georgia.
    Subsequent to the acquisition, we changed the name of Piedmont
    Bank to The PrivateBank. Piedmont&#146;s executive officers
    continue to manage The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia. We also
    announced plans in the fourth quarter of 2006 to grow using our
    <I>de novo </I>bank strategy by creating a new bank in Kansas
    City, Missouri and hiring a senior management team to lead that
    bank.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Since year-end 2001 to December&#160;31, 2006, we have grown our
    asset base at a compounded annual rate of 29% to
    $4.3&#160;billion. During the same period, loans have grown at a
    compounded annual rate of 35% to $3.5&#160;billion, deposits at
    a compounded annual rate of 33% to $3.6&#160;billion and core
    deposits at a compounded annual rate of 33% to
    $3.0&#160;billion. Wealth Management assets under management
    grew at a compounded annual rate of 32% to $2.9&#160;billion
    since year-end 2001. Diluted earnings per share (EPS) have grown
    at a compounded annual rate of 36% to $1.76 since year-end 2001.
    Excluding loans acquired from The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Michigan and The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia, loans grew at
    a compounded annual rate of 31% from year-end 2001 to
    December&#160;31, 2006. Excluding core deposits acquired from
    The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan and The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia, core deposits grew at a
    compounded annual rate of 29% from year-end 2001 to
    December&#160;31, 2006. Excluding wealth management assets
    acquired from The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan, The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia, and Lodestar, wealth management
    assets have grown at a five-year compounded annual rate of 25%.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For financial information regarding our six separate lines of
    business, The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago, The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan, The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    St. Louis, The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia, Wealth
    Management Services, and Holding Company Activities, see
    &#147;Operating Segments Results&#148; beginning on page&#160;51
    and &#147;Note&#160;2&#151;Operating Segments&#148; to our
    consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006, included on
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">page&#160;F-14.</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The profitability of our operations depends on our net interest
    income, provision for loan losses, non-interest income, and
    non-interest expense. Net interest income is dependent on the
    amount of and yields earned on, interest-earning assets as
    compared to the amount of and rates paid on, interest-bearing
    liabilities. Net interest income is sensitive to changes in
    market rates of interest as well as to the execution of our
    asset/liability management strategy. The provision for loan
    losses is affected by changes in the loan portfolio,
    management&#146;s assessment of the collectability of the loan
    portfolio, loss experience, as well as economic and market
    factors. Non-interest income consists primarily of wealth
    management fee revenue, mortgage banking income, bank owned life
    insurance and to a lesser extent, fees for ancillary banking
    services. Net securities gains/losses and net gains/losses on an
    interest rate swap are also included in non-interest income.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Critical
    Accounting Policies</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Generally accepted accounting principles are complex and require
    management to apply significant judgment to various accounting,
    reporting and disclosure matters. Management must use
    assumptions
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    39
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    and estimates to apply these principles where actual
    measurements are not possible or practical. Management&#146;s
    Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
    Operations should be read in conjunction with our consolidated
    financial statements included herein. Reference should also be
    made to our significant accounting policies set out in the notes
    to consolidated financial statements, beginning on
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">page&#160;F-8.</FONT>
    Below is a discussion of our critical accounting policies. These
    policies are critical because they are highly dependent upon
    subjective or complex judgments, assumptions and estimates.
    Changes in such estimates may have a significant impact on the
    financial statements. Actual results could differ from those
    estimates. Management has reviewed the application of these
    policies with the Audit Committee of the Company&#146;s Board of
    Directors.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The accounting policies that we view as critical to us are those
    relating to estimates and judgments regarding the determination
    of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses, the estimation
    of the valuation of goodwill and the useful lives applied to
    intangible assets, and income taxes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Allowance for
    Loan Losses</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We maintain an allowance for loan losses at a level management
    believes is sufficient to absorb credit losses inherent in our
    loan portfolio. The allowance for loan losses represents our
    estimate of probable losses in the portfolio at each balance
    sheet date and is based on a review of available and relevant
    information. The allowance contains provisions for probable
    losses that have been identified relating to specific borrowing
    relationships as well as probable losses inherent in our loan
    portfolio and credit undertakings that are not specifically
    identified. Our allowance for loan losses is reassessed
    quarterly to determine the appropriate level of the allowance.
    The amount of the allowance for loan losses is determined based
    on a variety of factors, including assessment of the credit risk
    of the loans in the portfolio, evaluation of watch list loans,
    volume of loans in the portfolio, delinquent loans, impaired
    loans, evaluation of current economic conditions in the market
    area, actual charge-offs and recoveries during the period and
    historical loss experience. The unallocated portion of the
    reserve involves the exercise of judgment by management and
    reflects various considerations, including management&#146;s
    view that the reserve should have a margin that recognizes the
    imprecision inherent in the process of estimating credit losses.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Management adjusts the allowance for loan losses by recording a
    provision for loan losses in an amount sufficient to maintain
    the allowance at the level determined appropriate. Loans are
    charged-off when deemed to be uncollectible by management. We
    believe that the allowance for loan losses is adequate to
    provide for estimated probable credit losses inherent in our
    loan portfolio. The allowance for loan losses as a percentage of
    total loans was 1.09% as of December&#160;31, 2006, compared to
    1.13% at December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Goodwill and
    Intangible Assets</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Goodwill represents the excess of the cost of an acquisition
    over the fair value of the net assets acquired. Other intangible
    assets represent purchased assets that also lack physical
    substance but can be separately distinguished from goodwill
    because of contractual or other legal rights or because the
    asset is capable of being sold or exchanged either on its own or
    in combination with a related contract, asset, or liability. We
    perform an annual goodwill impairment test in accordance with
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;142, which requires that goodwill and
    intangible assets that have indefinite lives no longer be
    amortized but be reviewed for impairment annually, or more
    frequently if certain indicators arise. Prior to the adoption of
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;142, goodwill was being amortized using the
    straight-line method over a period of 15&#160;years. Impairment
    losses on recorded goodwill, if any, will be recorded as
    operating expenses.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Goodwill is &#147;pushed down&#148; to business segments at
    acquisition. Fair values of reporting units are determined using
    either discounted cash flow analyses based on internal financial
    forecasts or, if available, market-based valuation multiples for
    comparable businesses. No impairment was identified as
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    40
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    a result of the testing performed during 2006 or 2005.
    Note&#160;2&#151;Operating Segments contains additional
    information regarding goodwill and the carrying values by
    segment.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Customer intangibles acquired in connection with the acquisition
    of Lodestar are amortized over an estimated useful life of
    15&#160;years. Customer intangibles acquired in connection with
    the acquisition of The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan are
    amortized over 10&#160;years using an accelerated method of
    amortization. Customer intangibles acquired in connection with
    the acquisition of The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia will be
    amortized over 8&#160;years using an accelerated method of
    amortization.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Income
    Taxes</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company is subject to the federal income tax laws of the
    United States, and the tax laws of the states and other
    jurisdictions where it conducts business. Due to the complexity
    of these laws, taxpayers and the taxing authorities may subject
    these laws to different interpretations. Management must make
    conclusions and estimates about the application of these
    innately intricate laws, related regulations, and case law. When
    preparing the Company&#146;s tax returns, management attempts to
    make reasonable interpretations of the tax laws. Taxing
    authorities have the ability to challenge management&#146;s
    analysis of the tax law or any reinterpretation management makes
    in its ongoing assessment of facts and the developing case law.
    Management assesses the reasonableness of its effective tax rate
    quarterly based on its current estimate of net income and the
    applicable taxes expected for the full year. On a quarterly
    basis, management also reviews circumstances and developments in
    tax law affecting the reasonableness of deferred tax assets and
    liabilities and reserves for contingent tax liabilities.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    41
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">CONSOLIDATED
    RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Net
    Income</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our net income for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006 was
    $37.8&#160;million or $1.76&#160;per diluted share, compared to
    $30.9&#160;million, or $1.46&#160;per diluted share for
    December&#160;31, 2005, and $25.3&#160;million, or
    $1.22&#160;per diluted share, for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2004. Our 2006 diluted earnings per share
    increased 21% as compared to 2005 earnings per share, and 2005
    diluted earnings per share increased 20% as compared to 2004
    earnings per share.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The increase in net income for 2006 compared to 2005 and 2005
    compared to 2004 was primarily attributable to increases in
    interest earning assets and growth in fee income, mainly from
    increases in wealth management revenue. Additionally, the
    acquisition of The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan was
    accretive in 2006 and 2005, including the consideration of all
    transaction costs. Our income growth was offset by a significant
    increase in interest expense, and growth in non-interest
    expense, evidenced by our efficiency ratio increasing to 54.45%
    at December&#160;31, 2006 from 52.37% at December&#160;31, 2005
    and 52.26% at December&#160;31, 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Net Interest
    Income</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net interest income is the difference between interest income
    and fees on earning assets and interest expense and amortization
    of fees on deposits and borrowings. Interest income includes
    amortization of loan origination fees and costs recorded from
    loans. Interest expense includes amortization of prepaid fees on
    brokered deposits and issuance costs of trust preferred
    securities. Net interest margin represents the net interest
    income on a tax equivalent basis as a percentage of average
    earning assets during the period. Net interest margin reflects
    the spread between average yields earned on interest earning
    assets and the average rates paid on interest bearing deposits
    and borrowings. The volume of non-interest bearing funds,
    largely comprised of demand deposits and capital, also affects
    the net interest margin.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net interest income was $117.5&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006, compared to $96.4&#160;million for 2005,
    an increase of 22%. Both the volume of assets and liabilities
    and the corresponding rates earned and paid, affect net interest
    income. The increase in net interest income for 2006 is
    primarily attributable to growth in earning assets. Average
    earning assets for 2006 were $3.5&#160;billion compared to
    $2.8&#160;billion for 2005, an increase of 25%. Our net interest
    margin (on a tax equivalent basis) was 3.46% for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006 compared to 3.57% for the prior year.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net interest income was $96.4&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2005, compared to $73.5&#160;million for 2004,
    an increase of 31%. The increase in net interest income for 2005
    is primarily attributable to growth in earning assets. Average
    earning assets for 2005 were $2.8&#160;billion compared to
    $2.1&#160;billion for 2004, an increase of 33%. Our net interest
    margin (on a tax equivalent basis) was 3.57% for 2005 compared
    to 3.67% for the year ended December&#160;31,2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2006, increased volumes of interest earning assets at
    higher rates were offset by increased volumes of interest
    bearing liabilities at higher rates. Our cost of funds increased
    1.23% to 4.42% for 2006 compared to 3.19% for 2005, and our tax
    exempt yield on earning assets increased by 1.03% to 7.43% in
    2006 compared to 6.40% in 2005. Non-interest bearing funds
    impact net interest margin since they represent non-interest
    bearing sources of funds that are deployed in interest bearing
    assets. Non-interest bearing funds positively impacted net
    interest margin by 0.45% at December&#160;31, 2006 and by 0.36%
    at December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The yield curve became modestly negatively sloped during the
    early part of the third quarter in 2006 and began to become more
    severely negatively sloped late in the third quarter and during
    fourth quarter, which resulted in a decline in our net interest
    margin in comparison to the prior year. A large portion of
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    42
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    our funding is sensitive to movements in the short end of the
    yield curve, just as a large majority of our loan portfolio is
    effectively pegged off the prime rate.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2005, increased volumes of interest earning assets at
    higher rates were offset by increased interest rates on
    liabilities. Our cost of funds was greater during 2005 than
    2004, 3.19% compared to 2.13%, respectively, and our earning
    assets yielded 6.40% in 2005 compared to 5.53% in 2004.
    Non-interest bearing funds positively impacted net interest
    margin by 0.36% at December&#160;31, 2005 and by 0.27% at
    December&#160;31, 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2005, our net interest margin was impacted by increases
    in the costs of our average interest bearing liabilities
    throughout the year. During 2005, total cost of funds increased
    by 105&#160;basis points from 2004, as a result of volume
    increases and increases in wholesale funding costs, time deposit
    rates, and increased interest expense related to the
    $50.0&#160;million of trust preferred securities issued on
    June&#160;20, 2005 in connection with The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan acquisition. The 100&#160;basis
    point increase in our cost of funds was partially offset by
    improvements in our yield on earnings assets, which increased by
    92&#160;basis points during the year due primarily to increased
    loan volumes and increases in the prime rate, which increased
    190&#160;basis points over the course of the year. Margin was
    also compressed because of reduced dividends on our investment
    in FHLB (Chicago) stock. The Company&#146;s annualized yield on
    this investment was 5.50% in 2005 compared to 6.11% for 2004.
    During 2005, dividends received on our investment in FHLB
    (Chicago) stock represented $9.2&#160;million, or 5%, of our
    interest income on a tax equivalent basis, for the year,
    compared to 11% for the prior year.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    43
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 10%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=467 length=48 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(1)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Average balances were generally
    computed using daily balances.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>



<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(2)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Nonaccrual loans are included in
    the average balances and do not have a material effect on the
    average yield. Interest due on non-accruing loans was not
    material for the periods presented.<BR>
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(3)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">We adjust GAAP reported net
    interest income by the tax equivalent adjustment amount to
    account for the tax attributes on federally tax exempt municipal
    securities. The total tax equivalent adjustment reflected in the
    above table is $4.6&#160;million, $4.5&#160;million and
    $4.4&#160;million for the years ended December&#160;31, 2006,
    2005, and 2004, respectively. For GAAP purposes, tax benefits
    associated with federally tax-exempt municipal securities are
    reflected in income tax expense. The following table reconciles
    reported net interest income to net interest income on a tax
    equivalent basis for the periods presented:
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 8pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Reconciliation of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">year-to-date</FONT>
    net interest income to
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">year-to-date</FONT>
    net interest income<BR>
    on a tax equivalent basis<BR>
    (dollars in thousands)</FONT></B>

<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(4)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Yield on average interest-earning
    assets less rate on average interest-bearing liabilities.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>



<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(5)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Net interest income, on a
    tax-equivalent basis, divided by average interest-earning assets.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table shows the dollar amount of changes in
    interest income and interest expense by major categories of
    interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities
    attributable to changes in volume or rate or a mix of both, for
    the periods indicated, calculated on a tax equivalent basis.
    Volume variances are computed using the change in volume
    multiplied by the previous year&#146;s rate. Rate variances are
    computed using the changes in rate multiplied by the previous
    year&#146;s volume.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 3px double #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>

</TD>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>



<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 10%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=467 length=48 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(1)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Interest income on tax-advantaged
    investment securities reflects a tax-equivalent adjustment based
    on a marginal federal corporate tax rate of 35%. The total tax
    equivalent adjustment reflected in the above table is
    approximately $4.6&#160;million, $4.5&#160;million, and
    $4.4&#160;million, for the years ended 2006, 2005, and 2004.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Provision for
    Loan Losses</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We provide for an adequate allowance for loan losses that are
    probable and reasonably estimable in the portfolio. The
    provision for loan losses reflects management&#146;s latest
    assessment of the inherent losses in the loan portfolio. Our
    allowance for probable loan losses is reassessed quarterly to
    determine the appropriate level of the reserve. Our analysis is
    influenced by the following factors: credit quality of loans,
    the volume, type and quality of loans and commitments in the
    portfolio, historical loss experience, and economic conditions.
    A discussion of the allowance for loan losses and the factors on
    which provisions are based begins on page&#160;55.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    45
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The changes recorded in the components of the allowance for loan
    losses resulted in a provision for loan losses of
    $6.8&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006, up
    from $6.5&#160;million for 2005 and $4.4&#160;million for 2004.
    We added $202.9&#160;million of loans and $2.7&#160;million of
    allowance for loan loss from The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia
    at its acquisition date. In 2005, we added $315.6&#160;million
    of loans and $3.6&#160;million of allowance for loan loss from
    The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan at its acquisition date.
    The Chicago, St. Louis, and Michigan banks continued to
    experience strong loan growth in 2006 and 2005. Excluding loans
    acquired from The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia, loans grew
    26% from December&#160;31, 2005 to December&#160;31, 2006. Net
    charge-offs for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006 were
    $873,000 compared to net recoveries of $250,000 for the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2005 and net charge-offs of $513,000 for
    the year ended December&#160;31, 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Non-interest income increased by $4.2&#160;million or 22%, to
    $23.2&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006
    compared to $19.0&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2005. Non-interest income in 2006 includes net
    investment securities losses of $374,000, compared to net gains
    of $499,000 in the prior year period. The fair market value
    adjustment on a $25.0&#160;million
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">10-year</FONT> for
    three-month LIBOR interest rate swap resulted in gains of
    $64,000 for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006 compared to
    gains of $404,000 in the prior year period. The Company retired
    this interest rate swap in the third quarter of 2006. Mortgage
    banking income decreased to $3.3&#160;million from
    $3.9&#160;million in the prior year period. Banking and other
    services income increased by $1.8&#160;million over the prior
    year, due to growth in the Company during 2006. During 2005,
    non-interest income increased by $4.7&#160;million or 33% to
    $19.0&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2005
    compared to $14.3&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Wealth management fee revenue totaled $13.9&#160;million for
    2006, an increase of $4.0&#160;million, or 40%, from 2005 levels
    of $9.9&#160;million. The
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">year-over-year</FONT>
    increase in wealth management income was primarily due to the
    growth of net new business and change of fee structures for
    certain client relationships. Our trust business contributed
    $9.9&#160;million of revenue during the year compared to
    $6.3&#160;million during the prior year. Wealth Management
    assets under management increased 19% to $2.9&#160;billion at
    year-end 2006, compared to $2.4&#160;billion at
    December&#160;31, 2005. Lodestar&#146;s assets under management
    at December&#160;31, 2006 were $749.9&#160;million, The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan&#146;s assets under management
    were $524.4&#160;million and trust assets managed by The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago were $1.6&#160;billion at
    December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Wealth management fee revenue totaled $9.9&#160;million for
    2005, an increase of $1.6&#160;million, or 19%, from 2004 levels
    of $8.3&#160;million. The
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">year-over-year</FONT>
    increase in wealth management income was partially due to the
    inclusion of $753,000 of income generated by The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan since its acquisition on
    June&#160;20, 2005, and the addition of new business. Our trust
    business contributed $6.3&#160;million of revenue during the
    year compared to $4.6&#160;million during the prior year and
    reflects growth of net new business during 2005. Wealth
    Management assets under management increased 41% to
    $2.4&#160;billion at year-end 2005, compared to
    $1.7&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2004. Lodestar&#146;s
    assets under
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    46
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    management at December&#160;31, 2005 were $689.2&#160;million,
    The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan&#146;s assets under
    management were $506.5&#160;million and trust assets managed by
    The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago, were $1.4&#160;billion at
    December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Mortgage banking income was $3.3&#160;million during 2006
    compared to $3.9&#160;million during 2005 and $2.9&#160;million
    during 2004. The decrease in residential mortgage fee income
    between 2005 and 2006 is primarily due to a lower volume of
    loans sold as a result of decreased demand for residential real
    estate loans and management&#146;s decision to place more loans
    on the Company&#146;s balance sheet for asset liability
    management purposes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2006, 2005, and 2004 we recognized income of
    $1.6&#160;million, $1.4&#160;million, and $876,000,
    respectively, related to the increased cash surrender value of
    bank owned life insurance (BOLI) policies. Income recognized on
    this product increased in 2006 as compared to 2005 primarily due
    to increases in the underlying policy yields. BOLI income
    recognized in 2005 increased as compared to 2004 primarily due
    to the inclusion of $96,000 of BOLI income from The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#151; Michigan&#146;s $5.3&#160;million BOLI
    policy. These policies cover certain higher-level employees who
    are deemed to be significant contributors to us. All employees
    included in this policy are aware and have consented to the
    coverage. The cash surrender value of BOLI at December&#160;31,
    2006 was $42.5&#160;million, compared to $40.9&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2005 and $34.1&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2004, and is included in other assets on the
    balance sheet.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Non-interest
    Expense</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="68%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=lead -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Non-interest expense increased $16.3&#160;million, or 26%, to
    $79.1&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006
    compared to $62.7&#160;million for 2005. The growth in
    non-interest expense during 2006 is a result of increases in
    personnel-related expense, occupancy expense, professional fees,
    and wealth management fees. The increase in non-interest expense
    from the prior year reflects a full year of expenses from The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan and The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Wisconsin, compared to the prior year period. The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan incurred non-interest expense
    of $9.0&#160;million and The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Wisconsin
    incurred non-interest expense of $2.5&#160;million during 2006.
    Some additional expenses incurred during 2006 include
    approximately $615,000 of expenses recognized in conjunction
    with the move of our corporate headquarters into larger offices
    during the third quarter 2006, and $1.2&#160;million in expenses
    attributable to the fraud loss discovered during the fourth
    quarter 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Non-interest expense increased $14.5&#160;million or 30% to
    $62.7&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2005
    compared to $48.2&#160;million for 2004. Nearly half of the
    growth in non-interest expense during 2005 was due to the
    inclusion of expenses of The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Wisconsin,
    which opened in September 2005, and operating expenses from The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan since acquisition in June 2005.
    During 2005, The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan incurred
    non-interest expense of $5.2&#160;million
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    47
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    since the acquisition, and The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Wisconsin
    incurred $1.9&#160;million of non-interest expense in 2005.
    Additionally, other expenses increased from December&#160;31,
    2004 to December&#160;31, 2005 due to a charge of $980,000
    associated with the early redemption of the Company&#146;s
    outstanding 9.5% trust preferred securities that were redeemed
    on December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The periods presented include stock option expense of
    $2.0&#160;million in 2006, $2.8&#160;million in 2005 and
    $2.5&#160;million in 2004. Effective January&#160;1, 2006, the
    Company adopted the fair value recognition provisions of
    Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (SFAS) No. 123,
    &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation.&#148; The Company
    elected the modified-retrospective-transition method, which
    results in the restatement of prior periods by recognizing
    compensation cost in the amounts previously reported in the pro
    forma financial statement footnote disclosures. Compensation
    cost recognized includes the cost of all share-based payments
    granted, but not yet fully vested in all periods presented.
    Additionally, the balance of certain accounts has been adjusted
    on a cumulative basis to reflect the activity of periods that
    are not presented. The following table includes the adjustments
    to these accounts as of January&#160;1, 2005, the beginning of
    the earliest period presented.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Prior to January&#160;1, 2006, the Company accounted for its
    stock-based employee compensation plans under the recognition
    and measurement provisions of APB Opinion No.&#160;25,
    &#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees,&#148; and
    related Interpretations, as permitted by Statement of Financial
    Accounting Standards (SFAS) No.&#160;123, &#147;Accounting for
    Stock-Based Compensation.&#148; No stock based employee
    compensation was recognized in the Consolidated Statements of
    Income in periods prior to the restatements under
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123R, as all options granted under the
    Company&#146;s compensation plans had an exercise price equal to
    the market value of the underlying common stock on the date of
    grant.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Prior to the adoption of SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123R, the Company
    presented all tax benefits of deductions resulting from the
    exercise of stock options and vesting of restricted shares as
    operating cash flows in the Statement of Cash Flows.
    SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123R requires the cash flows resulting from
    the tax benefits of these tax deductions in excess of the
    compensation cost recognized for those share-based payments (the
    excess tax benefits) be classified as financing cash flows. The
    excess tax benefit in financing cash flows was $1.4&#160;million
    in 2006 and $1.2&#160;million in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2006, total unrecognized compensation
    costs related to unvested stock options was $8.0&#160;million
    with a weighted average remaining life of 3.6&#160;years.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table shows our operating efficiency over the last
    three years:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 0pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 10%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=467 length=48 -->



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Non-interest expense less non-interest income divided by average
    total assets.</TD>
</TR>



<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (2) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    Non-interest expense divided by the sum of net interest income,
    on a tax equivalent basis, plus non-interest income. Please
    refer to the footnotes on page&#160;45 for a reconciliation of
    net interest income to net interest income on a tax-equivalent
    basis.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our efficiency ratio (on a tax-equivalent basis), which measures
    the percentage of net revenue that is expended as non-interest
    expense, for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006 increased to
    54.5%, as
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    48
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    compared to 52.4% for the year ended December&#160;31, 2005 and
    52.3% for the year ended December&#160;31, 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our efficiency ratio during 2006 reflects the impact of
    substantial increases in our non-interest expense. On a
    tax-equivalent basis, this ratio indicates that during 2006 we
    spent 54 cents to generate each dollar of revenue, compared to
    52 cents in 2005 and 2004. During 2006 we continued to focus on
    expansion at the Company, as evidenced with the opening of a new
    office in Chesterfield, Missouri, expansion of our Oak Brook and
    Geneva offices to new space, as well as the relocation of our
    corporate headquarters. Additionally, the opening of the <I>de
    novo </I>office in Kansas City, and the purchase of The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia, had a modestly negative impact
    on the efficiency ratio in 2006. With continued strong growth in
    the balance sheet and fee income over the course of 2007, and as
    we more fully lever the investment made in these new offices, we
    expect our efficiency ratio to incrementally decrease to the
    lower 50% range by the end of 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Salary and employee benefit expense increased 21% to
    $43.9&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006
    from $36.3&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31,
    2005. During 2006, we added 85 full time equivalent employees,
    an increase of 22%, to approximately 471&#160;full-time
    equivalent employees from 386 at December&#160;31, 2005. This
    includes the addition
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">and/or</FONT>
    promotion of 34 Managing Directors and Associate Managing
    Directors. The Kansas City and Atlanta offices added 15 managing
    directors to the Company during the fourth quarter. The increase
    in salary and benefit expense in 2006 also includes a full year
    of expenses for The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Salary and employee benefit expense increased 27% to
    $36.3&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2005
    from $28.5&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31,
    2004. During 2005, we added 125 full time equivalent employees,
    73 of those through the acquisition of The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan, to approximately
    386&#160;full-time equivalent employees from 261 at
    December&#160;31, 2004, an increase of 48%. This includes the
    addition
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">and/or</FONT>
    promotion of 34 Managing Directors and Associate Managing
    Directors year over year, 18 of which are managing directors at
    The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan. The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan incurred salaries and benefits
    expense of $3.0&#160;million during 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Professional fees, which include fees paid for legal,
    accounting, consulting, and information systems consulting
    services, increased 50% to $6.8&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006 from $4.6&#160;million for 2005 and
    $4.3&#160;million for 2004. The increase is primarily due to
    higher fees from the continued growth and expansion of the
    Company. The increase is also due to legal and consulting fees
    of $300,000 relating to the fraud loss investigation that
    occurred during the fourth quarter of 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Wealth management fees paid to third party investment managers
    increased 147% to $2.7&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006, from $1.1&#160;million in 2005 and
    $731,000 in 2004. This increase in fees paid to third party
    investment managers is due to the increase in assets managed by
    Wealth Management during 2006 and from the restructuring of
    certain fee arrangements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Marketing expenses increased to $4.3&#160;million for the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2006, from $3.5&#160;million for the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2005 and $2.5&#160;million for the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2004. Marketing expenses included
    approximately $1.1&#160;million of expense incurred by The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan in 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2006, the main focus of information technology
    expenditures was in two areas. The information technology
    infrastructure was upgraded in association with the multiple
    office relocations that occurred during the year and The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago implemented a Storage Area
    Network solution to improve storage capacity and document
    retrieval. In 2005, we upgraded the existing wire transfer
    system in Chicago, implemented an enhanced data replication and
    recovery solution, and further strengthened our data management
    strategy.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The other expense category of non-interest expense consists
    primarily of postage, telephone, delivery, office supplies,
    training and other miscellaneous expenses. Other expenses
    increased by 16% from prior year, principally due to the asset
    write off related to the fraud loss that occurred during the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    49
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    fourth quarter of 2006. The total expense incurred from the
    fraud loss was $1.2&#160;million, of which $918,000 related to
    the asset write-off in other expense and $300,000 related to
    professional fees for investigating the loss. During 2005 other
    expense increased 90% from 2004, principally due to a charge of
    $980,000 associated with the early redemption of the
    Company&#146;s outstanding 9.5% trust preferred securities that
    were redeemed on December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2006, we amortized $628,000 in intangible assets,
    $170,000 of which is related to our acquisition of a controlling
    interest in Lodestar in 2002, $440,000 of which is related to
    our acquisition of The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan in June
    2005, and $18,000 of which is related to the acquisition of The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia in December 2006. In 2005, we
    amortized $411,000 in intangible assets, $168,000 of which is
    related to our acquisition of a controlling interest in Lodestar
    and $243,000 of which is related to our acquisition of The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan in June 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Minority Interest
    Expense</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On December&#160;30, 2002, The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago
    acquired an 80% controlling interest in Lodestar. The Company
    records its 20% noncontrolling interest in Lodestar related to
    Lodestar&#146;s results of operations in minority interest
    expense on the consolidated statement of income. For the years
    ended December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, we recorded $330,000 and
    $307,000 of minority interest expense, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Off-Balance Sheet
    Arrangements and other Contractual Obligations and
    Commitments</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We do not have material off-balance sheet arrangements. We have
    various financial obligations, including contractual obligations
    and commitments that may require future cash payments. The
    following table presents, as of December&#160;31, 2006,
    significant fixed and determinable contractual obligations to
    third parties which are expected to become due and payable
    during the period specified.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our operating lease obligations represent short- and long-term
    lease and rental payments for facilities, equipment, and certain
    software or data processing. During 2006, we entered into new
    lease agreements for our existing Wilmette office, and for new
    space for our Oakbrook, and Geneva, Illinois offices. Our
    corporate headquarters relocated in the third quarter 2006 and
    assumed a new lease. Our
</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    new office in Chesterfield, Missouri entered into a new lease
    during 2006 and, as a result of the acquisition of The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia, we added leases for office
    space at three locations in Georgia.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Commitments to extend credit, including loan commitments,
    standby letters of credit, and commercial letters of credit do
    not necessarily represent future cash requirements, because
    these commitments may expire without being drawn upon.
    Information on commitments and letters of credit can be found on
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">page&#160;F-39.</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Our commitments to fund civic and community investments, which
    represent future cash outlays for the construction and
    development of properties for low-income housing, small business
    real estate, and historic tax credit projects that qualify for
    CRA purposes, are not included in the contractual obligations
    table above. The timing and amounts of these commitments are
    projected based upon the financing arrangements provided in each
    project&#146;s partnership or operating agreement, and could
    change due to variances in the construction schedule, project
    revisions, or the cancellation of the project. We continue to
    reach out to every market we serve through our community
    development efforts.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
