<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The effective income tax rate varies from statutory rates
    principally due to certain interest income that is tax-exempt
    for federal or state purposes, and certain expenses that are
    disallowed for tax purposes. The decrease in the effective tax
    rate for 2006 compared to 2005 is primarily the result of the
    release of certain reserves mostly due to the expiration of the
    statute of limitations. The increase in the effective tax rate
    for 2005 as compared to 2004 reflects the growth in pre-tax
    income of 31% and the decrease in federally tax-exempt municipal
    securities income of 2% year over year. The average balance of
    municipal securities was $206.8 million in 2005 compared to
    $212.9&#160;million in 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Operating
    Segments Results</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As described in Note&#160;2 to the consolidated financial
    statements, our operations consist of six primary business
    segments: The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago, The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; St.&#160;Louis, The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan, The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Georgia, Wealth Management, and the Holding Company. The
    PrivateBank Mortgage Company results are included in The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago since June&#160;15, 2004, the
    date of our acquisition of Corley Financial. The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Wisconsin&#146;s results are included in
    the results of The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; St. Louis, because
    The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Wisconsin was not granted a separate
    charter until January&#160;2, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The profitability of The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago is
    primarily dependent on the net interest income, provision for
    loan losses, non-interest income and non-interest expense. Net
    income for The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago for the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2006 increased 13% to $39.4&#160;million
    from $34.9&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31,
    2005. Net income for The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago for the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2005 increased 32% to
    $34.9&#160;million from $26.4&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2004.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    51
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For 2006, the net income growth for The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Chicago resulted from improvements in net interest income, which
    was primarily driven by increases in loan volumes and yields
    offset by a significant increase in interest expense and
    non-interest expense. Net interest income for The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006 increased to $90.7&#160;million from
    $79.4&#160;million, or 14% primarily due to growth in earning
    assets. Total loans increased by 27% to $2.4&#160;billion during
    2006 as compared to $1.9&#160;billion in 2005. The majority of
    the loan growth for 2006 occurred in the commercial real estate,
    commercial, and construction loan categories. Total deposits
    increased by 17% to $2.5&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2006
    from $2.2&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2005. Growth in
    money market deposits and other time deposits accounted for the
    majority of the deposit growth.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net interest income for The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago for
    the year ended December&#160;31, 2005 increased to
    $79.4&#160;million from $63.2&#160;million in 2004, or 26%
    primarily due to growth in earning assets. Total loans increased
    by 29% to $1.9&#160;billion during 2005 as compared to
    $1.5&#160;billion in 2004, or $426.0&#160;million of growth. The
    majority of the loan growth for 2005 occurred in the commercial
    real estate and construction loan categories. Total deposits
    increased by 28% to $2.2&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2005
    from $1.7&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2004. Growth in
    money market deposits and non-interest bearing deposits, as well
    as increased utilization of brokered deposits, accounted for the
    majority of the deposit growth.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; St. Louis</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net income for The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; St. Louis for the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2006 increased 48% to
    $3.4&#160;million from $2.3&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2005. Net income for The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; St.&#160;Louis for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2005 decreased to $2.3&#160;million from
    $2.8&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2004, due
    to The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Wisconsin&#146;s net loss of
    $1.3&#160;million in 2005, its first year of operation.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net interest income for The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; St. Louis
    for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006 increased to
    $15.6&#160;million from $11.4&#160;million, or 37% primarily due
    to growth in earning assets. Net interest income for the year
    ended December&#160;31, 2005 increased to $11.4&#160;million
    from $7.7&#160;million during 2004. Total loans increased by
    24%, or $80.1&#160;million, to $413.5&#160;million during 2006
    as compared to 2005, due primarily to growth in commercial real
    estate loans, construction, and commercial loans. Loans
    increased by $127.3 to $333.4&#160;million during 2005 as
    compared to loans at December&#160;31, 2004. Total deposits
    increased by $77.5&#160;million to $413.5&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2006 from $336.0&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2005. The deposit growth resulted from
    increases in money market deposits and other time deposits. For
    the year ended December&#160;31, 2005, deposits increased by
    $136.0&#160;million to $336.0&#160;million from
    $200.0&#160;million in 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net income for The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan was
    $5.5&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006.
    From its acquisition date, June&#160;20, 2005, through
    December&#160;31, 2005&#160;net income was $2.3&#160;million.
    Net interest income for 2006 was $17.4&#160;million, compared to
    $8.2&#160;million for the period June&#160;20, 2005 to
    December&#160;31, 2005. Total loans at December&#160;31, 2006
    were $503.2&#160;million, an increase of $105.4&#160;million, or
    26%, from $397.8&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2005. Total
    deposits increased 27% during 2006 to $418.1&#160;million at
    year ended December&#160;31, 2006 as compared to
    $328.9&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia&#146;s results of operations
    are included since the date of acquisition, December&#160;13,
    2006. Net income for The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia for the
    period December&#160;13, 2006 through December&#160;31, 2006 was
    $148,000. Net interest income for the period was $438,000. Total
    loans at December&#160;31, 2006 were $200.5&#160;million and
    total deposits were $202.8&#160;million.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    52
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Wealth
    Management</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Wealth Management includes investment management, personal trust
    and estate services, custodial services, retirement accounts and
    brokerage and investment services. Consolidated Wealth
    Management assets under management increased by 19%, or
    $465.4&#160;million, to $2.9&#160;billion at December&#160;31,
    2006 as compared to $2.4&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2005.
    Lodestar&#146;s assets under management at December&#160;31,
    2006 were $749.9&#160;million, compared to $689.2&#160;million
    at December&#160;31, 2005. This growth was due to the addition
    of new assets under management and portfolio performance. At
    December&#160;31 2006, Lodestar assets under management include
    $120.1&#160;million of assets managed by the Wealth Management
    department for clients who have selected Lodestar as investment
    adviser, compared to $109.2&#160;million in 2005. Excluding
    Lodestar and Michigan, Wealth management assets under management
    were $1.6&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2006, compared to
    $1.2&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2005. Wealth management
    fee revenue increased to $13.9&#160;million in 2006 compared to
    $10.0&#160;million in 2005 and $8.3&#160;million in 2004.
    Lodestar fee income increased by $330,000, or 9%, during 2006 as
    compared to 2005. Net income for our Wealth Management segment
    increased to $1.7&#160;million for the year ended
    December&#160;31, 2006 from $967,000 for the same period in 2005
    and up from $1.4&#160;million for 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Holding
    Company</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Holding Company activities consist of parent company only
    matters. The Holding Company&#146;s most significant assets are
    its net investments in its five banking subsidiaries, The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago, The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    St.&#160;Louis, The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan, The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Wisconsin, The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Georgia, and our mortgage banking subsidiary, The PrivateBank
    Mortgage Company. Holding Company activities are reflected
    primarily by interest expense on borrowings and operating
    expenses of the parent company. Recurring holding company
    operating expenses consist primarily of compensation
    (amortization of restricted stock awards, stock options, and
    other salary expense) and miscellaneous professional fees.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Holding Company activities segment reported a net loss of
    $11.8&#160;million for the year ended December&#160;31, 2006
    compared to the net loss of $7.0&#160;million for the same
    period in 2005. For the year ended 2004, the Holding Company
    Activities segment reported a net loss of $3.7&#160;million.
    During 2006, net interest expense increased from
    $4.1&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2005 to $8.0&#160;million
    at December&#160;31, 2006 due to increased borrowings. On
    December&#160;12, 2006 the Company amended its
    $65.0&#160;million credit facility entered into on
    September&#160;29, 2005 with LaSalle Bank N.A.
    (&#147;LaSalle&#148;). The amended agreement provides for an
    additional $25.0&#160;million in senior debt and an additional
    $25.0&#160;million of subordinated debt borrowing capacity under
    the Company&#146;s existing credit facility with LaSalle.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The amended credit facility is comprised of a $65.0&#160;million
    senior debt facility and $50.0&#160;million of subordinated
    debt. The senior debt facility is comprised of a $250,000 term
    loan with a maturity date of December&#160;31, 2017 and a
    revolving loan with a maturity date of December&#160;31, 2007.
    Management expects to renew the revolving loan on an annual
    basis. The subordinated debt matures on December&#160;31, 2017.
    The interest rate on the senior debt facility resets quarterly,
    and is based on, at the Company&#146;s option, either
    LaSalle&#146;s prime rate or three-month LIBOR plus
    120&#160;basis points, with a floor of 3.50%. The interest rate
    on the subordinated debt resets quarterly, and is equal to
    three-month LIBOR plus 135&#160;basis points, with a floor of
    3.50%. The subordinated debt qualifies as Tier&#160;2 capital
    under applicable rules and regulations promulgated by the Board
    of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At December&#160;31, 2006, the Company had $45.25&#160;million
    outstanding on the senior debt facility and $40.0&#160;million
    of subordinated debt outstanding. The Company expects to further
    draw down on the facilities over the next year to support
    continued balance sheet growth.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    53
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">FINANCIAL
    CONDITION</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Total
    Assets</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total assets were $4.3&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2006,
    an increase of $764.1&#160;million, or 22%, from
    $3.5&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2005. The balance sheet
    growth was accomplished mainly through strong organic loan
    growth throughout the Company and the inclusion of the assets of
    The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia. Excluding loans of The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia at acquisition date, loans grew
    by 26% from December&#160;31, 2005. The growth in assets
    experienced during 2006 was funded primarily through growth in
    core deposits. Excluding core deposits of The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia at acquisition date, core
    deposits grew by 25% from December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total assets were $3.5&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2005 an
    increase of $958.6&#160;million, or 38%, from $2.5&#160;billion
    at December&#160;31, 2004. The balance sheet growth during 2005
    was due to the inclusion of $462.9&#160;million in assets of The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan and loan growth throughout the
    Company. The growth in assets experienced during 2005 was funded
    primarily through growth in core deposits and increases in
    brokered deposits.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Loans</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total loans increased to $3.5&#160;billion at December&#160;31,
    2006, an increase of $891.9&#160;million or 34%, from
    $2.6&#160;billion at December&#160;31, 2005. The Company has
    benefited from strong organic loan growth during 2006. Excluding
    loans of The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia at acquisition date
    of $202.9&#160;million, loans grew by 26% year over year.
    Company-wide, loan growth in 2006 has occurred primarily in the
    commercial real estate, commercial and construction categories.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table sets forth the loan portfolio by category as
    of December&#160;31 for the previous five fiscal years:
</DIV>

    <BR>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Allowance for
    Loan Losses</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Loan quality is monitored by management and reviewed by the loan
    committees of the Board of Directors of the banks on a quarterly
    basis. The amount of additions to the allowance for loan losses,
    which is charged to earnings through the provision for loan
    losses, is determined based on a variety of factors, including
    assessment of the credit risk of the portfolio, evaluation of
    loans classified as special mention,
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">sub-standard</FONT>
    and doubtful loans, delinquent loans, evaluation of other watch
    list credits, evaluation of current economic conditions in the
    market area, actual charge-offs during the year, historical loss
    experience and industry loss averages. The unallocated portion
    of the reserve involves the exercise of judgment by management
    and reflects various considerations, including management&#146;s
    view that the reserve should have a margin that recognizes the
    imprecision inherent in the process of estimating credit losses.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    55
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We maintain an allowance for loan losses sufficient to absorb
    credit losses inherent in our loan portfolio. The allowance for
    loan losses represents our estimate of probable losses in the
    portfolio at each balance sheet date and is supported by
    available and relevant information. The allowance contains
    provisions for probable losses that have been identified
    relating to specific borrowing relationships, as well as
    probable losses inherent in the loan portfolio and credit
    undertakings that are not specifically identified.
    Management&#146;s application of the methodology for determining
    the allowance for loan losses resulted in an allowance for loan
    losses of $38.1&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2006 compared
    with $29.4&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2005. The increase
    in the allowance for loan losses from December&#160;31, 2005
    reflects the addition of $2.7&#160;million of loan loss reserves
    as a result of the acquisition of The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Georgia, management&#146;s judgment about the comprehensive risk
    of real estate related lending in our various markets, the
    addition of new lending personnel as well as strong loan growth
    from all existing offices in 2006. We believe that the allowance
    for loan losses is adequate to provide for estimated probable
    credit losses inherent in our loan portfolio.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The allowance for loan losses as a percentage of total loans was
    1.09% at December&#160;31, 2006, down from 1.13% at
    December&#160;31, 2005. Net charge-offs totaled $873,000 for the
    year ended December&#160;31, 2006 versus net recoveries of
    $250,000 in 2005. The provision for loan losses was
    $6.8&#160;million for the twelve months ended December&#160;31,
    2006, versus $6.5&#160;million in the prior year period. The key
    factors in determining the level of provision is our historical
    and anticipated charge-off rates and an analysis of credit
    ratings on the loans in our portfolio.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We believe our loan loss experience to date reflects the
    excellent credit quality of our loan portfolio. The following
    table shows changes in the allowance for loan losses resulting
    from additions to the allowance and loan charge-offs
    (recoveries) for each of the periods shown.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We considered various qualitative and quantitative factors about
    the loan portfolio in determining the level of the allowance for
    loan losses. Under our methodology, the allowance for loan
    losses is comprised of the following components:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">&#160;&#160;Allocated
    Inherent Component of the Reserve</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The allocated portion of the allowance for loan losses is based
    on loan type and allocated by loan risk within each loan type.
    The Company assigns each of its loans a risk rating at the time
    of loan origination and either confirms or changes the risk
    rating at the time of subsequent reviews, loan renewals or upon
    default. The loss allocations are based on a combination of a
    historical analysis of the Company&#146;s losses and adjustment
    factors deemed relevant by management. The adjustment factors
    take into account banking industry-wide loss statistics, current
    facts and circumstances, and long-term economic trends. During
    the second quarter 2005, the historical analysis was enhanced to
    include a five-year migration analysis of the Company&#146;s
    losses and the documentation of the loss adjustment factors was
    augmented.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The allocated inherent component of the reserve increased by
    $9.1&#160;million during 2006, from $26.5&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2005 to $35.6&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2006. The increase in the allocated portion of
    the reserve reflects higher loan volumes in every category,
    particularly commercial real estate and construction loans.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Specific
    Component of the Reserve</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For loans where management deems either the amount or the timing
    of the repayment to be significantly impaired, there are
    specific reserve allocations established. The specific reserve
    is based on a loan&#146;s current value compared to the present
    value of its projected future cash flows, collateral value or
    market value, as is relevant for the particular loan pursuant to
    SFAS&#160;114, &#147;Accounting by Creditors for Impairment of a
    Loan.&#148; As of December&#160;31, 2006, the specific component
    of the reserve increased to $291,000 from zero at
    December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    57
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Unallocated
    Inherent Components of the Reserve</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The unallocated inherent component of the reserve is based on
    management&#146;s review of other factors affecting the
    determination of probable losses inherent in the portfolio,
    which are not necessarily captured by the application of loss
    and loss adjustment factors. This portion of the reserve
    analysis involves the exercise of judgment and reflects
    consideration such as management&#146;s view that the reserve
    should have a margin that recognizes the imprecision inherent in
    the process of estimating credit losses.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The unallocated inherent component of the reserve decreased by
    $723,000 for 2006, from $2.9&#160;million at December&#160;31,
    2005 to $2.1&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Non-performing
    Loans</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table classifies our non-performing loans as of
    the dates shown:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</TD>
<TD colspan="2" nowrap align="center" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">
    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">2004</FONT></B>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    It is our policy to discontinue the accrual of interest income
    on any loan for which there exists reasonable doubt as to the
    payment of interest or principal. Nonaccrual loans are returned
    to an accrual status when the financial position of the borrower
    indicates there is no longer any reasonable doubt as to the
    payment of principal or interest.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Other than those loans reflected in the table above, we had no
    significant loans for which the terms had been renegotiated or
    restructured, or for which there were serious doubts as to the
    ability of the borrower to comply with repayment terms.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Potential Problem Loans.</I> In addition to those loans
    reflected in the table above, we have identified some loans
    through our problem loan identification process which exhibit a
    higher than normal credit risk. Loans in this category include
    loans with characteristics such as past maturity more than
    90&#160;days, those that have recent adverse operating cash flow
    or balance sheet trends, or loans that have general risk
    characteristics that management believes might jeopardize the
    future timely collection of principal and interest payments. The
    balance in this category at any reporting period can fluctuate
    widely based on the timing of cash collections, renegotiations
    and renewals. At December&#160;31, 2006, there were no potential
    problem loans that are not included above as nonaccrual, past
    due or restructured.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Nonaccrual loans were $3.8&#160;million as of December&#160;31,
    2006 compared to $663,000 at December&#160;31, 2005.
    Nonperforming loans include nonaccrual loans and accruing loans
    that are 90&#160;days or more delinquent. Nonperforming loans
    were $8.9&#160;million as of December&#160;31, 2006, compared to
    $943,000 at December&#160;31, 2005. Nonperforming loans were
    0.25%, and 0.04%, of total loans at December&#160;31, 2006 and
    December&#160;31, 2005, respectively. Nonperforming assets were
    0.23% and 0.04% of total assets as of December&#160;31, 2006 and
    December&#160;31, 2005, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At December&#160;31, 2006, the Company had $1.1&#160;million in
    other real estate owned (OREO). OREO is included in other assets
    on the balance sheet and we carry OREO at the fair value less
    estimated costs to sell. The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150;&#160;St.&#160;Louis had $930,000 of OREO
    relating to two properties in St.&#160;Louis and St.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    58
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Charles, Missouri. The OREO balance at December&#160;31, 2006
    also reflects $138,000 of OREO at The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150;&#160;Michigan and $32,000 of OREO
    acquired as part of our acquisition of The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150;&#160;Georgia.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <I>Loan&#160;Concentrations.</I> Loan concentrations are
    considered to exist when amounts are loaned to a multiple number
    of borrowers engaged in similar activities, which would cause
    them to be similarly impacted by economic or other conditions.
    At December&#160;31, 2006, commercial real estate loans and
    multi-family commercial real estate loans comprised 50% of our
    total loan portfolio of $3.5&#160;billion. Within this segment,
    loans secured by vacant land totaled $400.7&#160;million or 11%
    of the total loan portfolio. The majority of these loans have a
    take out commitment, a financially strong guarantor, or both.
    With respect to the remaining portion of the commercial loan
    portfolio, there were no concentrations of loans by collateral
    type that exceeded 10% of the total loan portfolio. Commercial
    real estate typically involves higher loan principal amounts,
    and the repayment of these loans generally is dependant, in
    large part, on the successful operation of the property securing
    the loan or the business conducted on the property securing the
    loan. These loans may be more adversely affected by general
    conditions in the real estate markets or in the economy.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Construction loans totaled $591.7&#160;million for 17% of our
    total loan portfolio. Over 50% of these loans were for the
    construction of 1-4&#160;unit residential dwellings. We have
    developed long-standing relationships with known builders and
    limit the amount of lending for speculative home building
    projects by developer as well as a percentage of the overall
    portfolio. With few exceptions our construction lending is with
    recourse to the owner/developer. These loans are secured by the
    underlying project and the progress of the project and
    collateral values are closely monitored. Commercial loans of
    $563.2&#160;million comprise 16% of our total loan portfolio.
    These loans are to a diverse group of businesses and are mostly
    secured
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">and/or</FONT>
    guaranteed. While we consider ourselves cash flow lenders, we
    structure the majority of our loans with multiple sources of
    repayment.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Due to our size and regional locations, our loans are
    geographically concentrated to borrowers residing in and secured
    by collateral located within the greater metropolitan areas of
    Chicago, Detroit, St.&#160;Louis, Atlanta and Milwaukee. Our
    geographic concentration in the Chicago metropolitan area
    lessened from the previous year with the continued growth of The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150;&#160;Michigan and The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150;&#160;St.&#160;Louis, which through
    December&#160;31, 2006 included the The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150;&#160;Wisconsin, along with the
    acquisition of PrivateBank&#160;&#150;&#160;Georgia. As we seek
    to expand our footprint in new markets, we believe the
    geographic concentration will continue to lessen.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Investment
    Securities</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Investments are comprised of federal funds sold, debt securities
    and equity investments. Federal funds sold are overnight
    investments in which, except for cash reserves, all remaining
    funds are invested. Our debt securities portfolio is primarily
    comprised of U.S.&#160;government agency obligations, municipal
    bonds, mortgage-backed pools and collateralized mortgage
    obligations. Our equity investments consist primarily of equity
    investments in FHLB (Des Moines), FHLB (Indianapolis), and FHLB
    (Atlanta).
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    All securities are classified as
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">available-for-sale</FONT>
    and may be sold as part of our asset/liability management
    strategy in response to changes in interest rates, liquidity
    needs or significant prepayment risk. Securities
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">available-for-sale</FONT>
    are carried at fair value, with related unrealized net gains or
    losses, net of deferred income taxes, recorded as an adjustment
    to equity capital. At December&#160;31, 2006, reported
    stockholders&#146; equity reflected unrealized securities gains
    net of tax of $5.9&#160;million. This represented a decrease of
    $1.6&#160;million from unrealized securities gains net of tax of
    $7.4&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Securities
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">available-for-sale</FONT>
    decreased to $496.8&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2006, down
    29% from $695.2&#160;million as of December&#160;31, 2005. The
    contraction in the investment security portfolio since
    December&#160;31, 2005 resulted primarily from the redemption of
    $138.5&#160;million of FHLB (Chicago) stock held by the Company
    in conjunction with its May 2006 withdrawal of membership from
    the FHLB
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    59
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    (Chicago). We held $30.0&#160;million in U.S.&#160;government
    agency obligations at December&#160;31, 2006, up from none held
    at December&#160;31, 2005. U.S.&#160;government agency mortgage
    backed securities and collateralized mortgage obligations
    decreased by $73.0&#160;million to $243.2 at December&#160;31,
    2006, from $316.2&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2005. We
    held no corporate collateralized mortgage obligations at
    December&#160;31, 2006 and December&#160;31, 2005. Tax-exempt
    municipal securities were $211.0&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2006 as compared to the year-end 2005 amount
    of $230.2&#160;million.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At December&#160;31, 2006, the Company&#146;s consolidated
    investment in Federal Home Loan&#160;Bank (FHLB) stock was
    $5.1&#160;million, compared to $142.4&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2005. The reduction in this investment
    reflects the redemption of $138.5&#160;million FHLB (Chicago)
    stock during the second quarter in connection with the
    Company&#146;s withdrawal from the FHLB (Chicago). The
    $5.1&#160;million of FHLB stock at December&#160;31, 2006 was
    comprised of $2.5&#160;million of FHLB (Indianapolis) stock,
    $1.4&#160;million of FHLB (Atlanta) stock, and $1.2&#160;million
    of FHLB (Des Moines) stock.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following tables show, respectively, the effective
    maturities of investment securities (based upon the amortized
    cost), by category, as of December&#160;31, 2006, and the
    weighted average yield (computed on a tax equivalent basis) for
    each range of maturities of securities, by category, as of
    December&#160;31, 2006. For the mortgage backed securities and
    collateralized mortgage obligations categories, the effective
    maturity and weighted average yield are based upon mortgage
    prepayment estimates. Actual
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    mortgage prepayments may vary due to changes in interest rates,
    economic conditions and other factors.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="37%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=lead -->
    <TD width="5%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=lead -->
    <TD width="6%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=lead -->
    <TD width="6%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=body -->

<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 10%; align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=467 length=48 -->



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (1) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The weighted average yield reflects a tax-equivalent adjustment
    based on a marginal federal corporate tax rate of 35% and the
    yields are derived from the amortized cost basis of investment
    securities.</TD>
</TR>



<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (2) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    We were required to maintain a ratio of 20:1 of FHLB borrowings
    to FHLB stock.</TD>
</TR>



<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (3) </TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    The weighted average yield reflects a tax credit of 6.91%.</TD>
</TR>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Deferred
    Taxes</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Net deferred tax assets are included in other assets and net
    deferred tax liabilities are included in other liabilities in
    the Company&#146;s Consolidated Balance Sheets. Included in net
    deferred tax assets at December&#160;31, 2006 is approximately
    $767,000 of net deferred tax assets acquired in the purchase of
    Piedmont Bancshares, Inc. These net deferred tax assets include
    a net operating loss carryforward of approximately
    $1.1&#160;million which expires in 2026. The Company believes it
    is more likely than not that
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    61
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    the deferred tax assets including the net operating loss
    carryforward will be realized based on reversing deferred tax
    liabilities and expected future taxable income.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Deposits and
    Funds Borrowed</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Total deposits of $3.6&#160;billion as of December&#160;31, 2006
    represented an increase of 26% from $2.8&#160;billion as of
    December&#160;31, 2005. Core deposits, which represent total
    deposits less brokered deposits, increased 32% to
    $3.0&#160;billion compared to $2.2&#160;billion at
    December&#160;31, 2005. Excluding core deposits of The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia at acquisition date, core
    deposits grew by 25% year over year. The PrivateBank&#160;&#150;
    Georgia had $177.7&#160;million in core deposits at
    December&#160;31, 2006. Brokered deposits were
    $589.3&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2006, up
    $2.7&#160;million from $586.6&#160;million at December&#160;31,
    2005. Brokered deposits were 17&#160;percent of total deposits
    at December&#160;31, 2006 compared to 21&#160;percent at
    December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In 2006, our interest bearing demand deposits as a percentage of
    total deposits decreased by 1% as compared to 2005 while our
    other time deposits as a percentage of total deposits increased
    by 6%. Money market deposit accounts increased by
    $303.3&#160;million to $1.6&#160;billion at December&#160;31,
    2006, as compared to $1.3&#160;billion at December&#160;31,
    2005. We experienced 61% growth in other time deposits and 24%
    growth in money market accounts during the year. Other time
    deposits increased by approximately $354.6&#160;million to
    $933.6&#160;million as compared to $579.0&#160;million at
    year-end 2005. Interest-bearing demand deposits increased
    $19.5&#160;million to $152.3&#160;million at December&#160;31,
    2006 compared to $132.8&#160;million at December&#160;31, 2005.
    Non-interest-bearing deposits were $300.7&#160;million as of
    December&#160;31, 2006, a $48.1&#160;million increase over the
    $252.6&#160;million reported as of December&#160;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table presents the balances of deposits by
    category and each category as a percentage of total deposits at
    December&#160;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Over the past several years, our clients have chosen to keep the
    maturities of their deposits short. We expect these short-term
    certificates of deposit to be renewed on terms and with
    maturities similar to those currently in place. In the event
    that certain of these certificates of deposits are not renewed
    and
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    62
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    the funds are withdrawn from the banks, those deposits will be
    replaced with traditional deposits, brokered deposits, borrowed
    money or capital, or we will liquidate assets to reduce our
    funding needs.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">

</TD>
</TR>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We continued to utilize brokered deposits as a source of funding
    for growth in our loan portfolio in 2006. As of
    December&#160;31, 2006, we held thirteen outstanding brokered
    deposits containing unexercised call provisions. We have
    brokered deposits with approximately twelve different brokers
    and we receive periodic information from other brokers regarding
    potential deposits.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The scheduled maturities of brokered deposits, net of
    unamortized prepaid broker commissions, as of December&#160;31,
    2006, for each quarter in 2007, and for the years 2008 through
    2011 and thereafter, are as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

    maturity date of 4/23/2024 callable monthly; and a
    $6.6&#160;million brokered deposit with a maturity date of
    6/30/2025, an original call date of 12/30/2005, and
    semi-annually thereafter.</TD>
</TR>



<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    (5) </TD>
    <TD></TD>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Membership in the FHLB system gives us the ability to borrow
    funds from the FHLB (Des Moines), the FHLB (Indianapolis), and
    the FHLB (Atlanta) under a variety of programs. We have
    periodically used the services of the FHLB for funding needs and
    other correspondent services. Our withdrawal as a member of the
    FHLB (Chicago) was completed during the second quarter 2006.
    Therefore, we are no longer able to borrow funds or participate
    in any of the other programs of the FHLB (Chicago); however, we
    anticipate that we will continue to be members of, and to take
    advantage of the programs offered by, the FHLB (Des Moines), the
    FHLB (Indianapolis), and the FHLB (Atlanta).
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2006, our reliance on FHLB borrowings as a funding source
    decreased by $161.6&#160;million from December&#160;31, 2005,
    mainly due to our withdrawal as a member of the FHLB (Chicago)
    in May 2006. FHLB borrowings totaled $83.5&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2006 compared to $245.1&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2005. At December&#160;31, 2006 our FHLB
    borrowings consisted of $45.0&#160;million from the FHLB
    (Indianapolis), $22.5&#160;million from the FHLB (Atlanta), and
    $16.0&#160;million from the FHLB (Des Moines). The FHLB requires
    us to pledge collateral in connection with obtaining FHLB
    advances. Our pledged collateral consists of residential real
    estate loans and certain qualifying multi-family loans and
    investment securities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On October&#160;31, 2005, the Company delivered to the FHLB
    (Chicago) written notice of its intent to withdraw its
    membership and obtain redemption of all of the FHLB (Chicago)
    stock held by the Company upon the effective date of the
    withdrawal. Pursuant to applicable regulation, the withdrawal
    and the FHLB (Chicago&#146;s) obligation to redeem the
    Company&#146;s stock was effective on May&#160;2, 2006 with the
    redemption of all shares of FHLB (Chicago) stock and payment of
    $138.5&#160;million to the Company. In addition, the Company
    sold and paid off its outstanding FHLB (Chicago) advances prior
    to its withdrawal and will not have access for a period of five
    years thereafter to advances from the FHLB (Chicago).
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company believes that adequate funding from a variety of
    wholesale funding sources, including brokered deposits and
    advances from the FHLB (Indianapolis), FHLB (Des Moines), or the
    FHLB (Atlanta) have been and will continue to be available to
    replace the FHLB (Chicago) advances on terms that will not have
    a material impact, either positively or negatively, on the
    Company&#146;s net interest margin.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table presents detail on our short-term borrowings
    for the years shown. For a detailed listing of all funds
    borrowed, see Note&#160;9 to the financial statements:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>

</TD>

</TD>

</TD>

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">2005</FONT></B>
</TD>

</TD>

    At December&#160;31, 2006, we had no FHLB letters of credit
    outstanding, compared to $12.6&#160;million in FHLB letters of
    credit outstanding at December&#160;31, 2005. The following
    table shows the maximum

    availability for and usage of FHLB advances and letters of
    credit for The PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Chicago, The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; St.&#160;Louis, The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Michigan, and The
    PrivateBank&#160;&#150; Georgia.

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We accept deposits from a variety of municipal entities.
    Typically, these municipal entities require that banks pledge
    marketable securities to collateralize these public deposits. At
    December&#160;31, 2006 and 2005, we had approximately
    $359.5&#160;million and $400.7&#160;million, respectively, of
    securities collateralizing such public deposits. Deposits
    requiring pledged assets are not considered to be core deposits
    for regulatory purposes and the assets that are pledged as
    collateral for these deposits are not deemed to be liquid assets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On December&#160;12, 2006 the Company amended its
    $65.0&#160;million credit facility entered into on
    September&#160;29, 2005 with LaSalle Bank. The amended agreement
    provides for an additional $25.0&#160;million in senior debt and
    an additional $25.0&#160;million of subordinated debt borrowing
    capacity under the Company&#146;s existing credit facility with
    LaSalle.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The amended credit facility is comprised of a $65.0&#160;million
    senior debt facility and $50.0&#160;million of subordinated
    debt. The senior debt facility is comprised of a $250,000 term
    loan with a maturity date of December&#160;31, 2017 and a
    revolving loan with a maturity date of December&#160;31, 2007.
    Management expects to renew the revolving loan on an annual
    basis. The subordinated debt matures on December&#160;31, 2017.
    The interest rate on the senior debt facility resets quarterly,
    and is based on, at the Company&#146;s option, either
    LaSalle&#146;s prime rate or three-month LIBOR plus
    120&#160;basis points, with a floor of 3.50%. The interest rate
    on the subordinated debt resets quarterly, and is equal to
    three-month LIBOR plus 135&#160;basis points, with a floor of
    3.50%. The subordinated debt qualifies as Tier&#160;2 capital
    under applicable rules and regulations promulgated by the Board
    of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    At December&#160;31, 2006, the Company had $45.3&#160;million
    outstanding on the senior debt facility and $40.0&#160;million
    of subordinated debt outstanding. The Company expects to further
    draw down on the facilities over the next year to support
    continued balance sheet growth.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Risk
    Management</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We are exposed to market risk from changes in interest rates
    that could affect our results of operations and financial
    condition. We manage our exposure to these market risks through
    our regular operating and financing activities. During 2001, we
    began to hedge interest rate risk through the use of derivative
    financial instruments. We occasionally use derivative financial
    instruments as a risk management tool.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Interest Rate
    Risk</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We use a combination of financial instruments, including
    medium-term and short-term financings and variable-rate debt
    instruments and, to a lesser extent, interest rate swaps to
    manage the interest rate mix of our balance sheet and related
    cash flows.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As market interest rates continued to decline to historic lows
    in the second half of 2002, the value of our long-term
    tax-exempt bank-qualified municipal bond portfolio increased. In
    order to protect this gain
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    65
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 88%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL PAGE -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    should rates rise, we entered into a $25.0&#160;million swap
    agreement whereby we sold the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">10-year</FONT> swap
    and bought three-month LIBOR to act as an economic hedge to a
    portion of our long municipal bonds. Given the current interest
    rate environment, we deemed it appropriate to retire this
    interest rate swap during the third quarter 2006. Another
    interest rate swap we entered into was designated as a fair
    value hedge of a fixed rate $20.0&#160;million brokered deposit.
    We agreed to receive a 4.6% fixed rate in exchange for payment
    of three month LIBOR minus 12.5&#160;basis points on an agreed
    upon notional amount of $20.0&#160;million. This interest rate
    swap matured on June&#160;28, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Changes in market rates give us the opportunity to make changes
    to our investment security portfolio as part of the
    implementation of our asset liability management strategies.
    Throughout 2005 and 2006, we continued to replace specific
    investment securities with alternative investment securities
    with greater risk/reward parameters on a selective basis. Our
    net interest margin decreased to 3.46% during 2006, as compared
    to 3.57% at December&#160;31, 2005. During 2005 and the first
    half of 2006 our costs on wholesale funds, short-term borrowings
    and deposits outpaced the increase in earning asset yields due
    to the shape of the yield curve and increases in the prime rate
    of interest. Approximately 67% of the loan portfolio is indexed
    to the prime rate of interest or otherwise adjusts with other
    short-term interest rates.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    We have not changed our interest rate risk management strategy
    from the prior year and do not foresee or expect any significant
    changes in our exposure to interest rate fluctuations, but we
    will continue to consider the use of interest rate swaps on our
    debt obligations in the future depending on changes in market
    rates of interest.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica">Capital
    Resources</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Stockholders&#146; equity increased to $297.1&#160;million at
    December&#160;31, 2006, an increase of $58.5&#160;million from
    December&#160;31, 2005 stockholders&#146; equity of
    $238.6&#160;million. The Company and its banking subsidiaries
    are subject to regulatory capital requirements administered by
    federal banking agencies. Capital adequacy guidelines and prompt
    corrective action regulations involve quantitative measures of
    assets, liabilities and certain off-balance-sheet items
    calculated under regulatory accounting practices. Capital
    amounts and classifications are also subject to qualitative
    judgments by regulators about components, risk weightings and
    other factors, and the regulators can lower classifications in
    certain areas. Failure to meet various capital requirements can
    initiate regulatory action that could have a direct material
    effect on the financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The prompt corrective action regulations provide five
    classifications: well-capitalized, adequately capitalized,
    undercapitalized, significantly undercapitalized, and critically
    undercapitalized, although these terms are not used to represent
    overall financial condition. If a banking subsidiary is not
    &#147;well capitalized,&#148; regulatory approval is required to
    accept brokered deposits. If undercapitalized, capital
    distributions are limited as is asset growth and expansion and
    plans for capital restoration are required.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    66
</DIV><!-- END LOGICAL PAGE -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
